1.40.text:
ETHAN: Your fingers
freeze up and get cold.

2.87.text:
And they feel like you've got
a glove on even when you don't.

6.50.text:
It becomes almost impossible
to do some of the things

9.43.text:
I'm handling metal
with bare hands.

12.57.text: MAN 1: Put it in your mouth.

18.80.text:
Well, I don't really
want to lose the nuts

20.33.text:
and washers in the
snow, so I've just

23.73.text: been putting them in my mouth.

25.10.text:
But they're a bit cold, so
I've been ripping bits of skin

51.23.text:
become a part of
helping us understand

54.73.text:
Once we get a few
storms through,

56.10.text:
hopefully it'll give
us some good data.

69.17.text:
CHRISTIAN: It's a huge
relief to be done setting up.

72.33.text:
Now we have our base
camp for future seasons.

75.23.text:
We've figured out
what we needed to.

77.73.text:
Everything worked the
way it should have.

79.53.text:
We showed that, you know,
the Ross Ice Shelf program

83.23.text:
We have scientists from
all different disciplines

87.00.text:
Whatever we're going to
discover, it's going to be new.

88.37.text:
And it's going to
be interesting.

102.70.text:
MAN 1: So we're going
to stage some stuff

106.03.text:
So we've left 50-odd
drums of fuel over there.

109.43.text:
Next year, we'll be coming
straight back out to this side.

112.20.text:
And we'll have kind of the basis
of the camp already set up.

116.67.text:
Here's poo, some
of our food waste,

122.17.text:
We'll get rid of a
fair bit of that.

129.47.text: part of your job, I bet.

131.03.text:
The Scott Base, they
can only process one

133.37.text: of those pee barrels every day.

136.83.text:
So we wanted to get as many as
we can back to Scott Base now

141.20.text:
It's going to take a month to
get rid of our pees from here.

149.77.text:
MAN 1: Basically, it will
take away four of our people,

152.20.text:
leaving us with a
little small crew

161.23.text:
WOMAN 2: What is this
luxury accommodation?

163.80.text:
All-- all this
space on our feet.
